title: en.wikipedia.org_wiki_2025_Nepalese_Gen_Z_protests
transformers_text: Protesters Government of Nepal De centralised leadership In September 2025 large scale anti corruption protests and demonstrations took place across Nepal predominantly organized by Generation Z students and young citizens 8 Also known as the Gen Z protests a 9 they began following a nationwide ban on numerous social media platforms including YouTube Facebook and What s App and they incorporated the public's frustration with corruption and display of wealth by government officials and their families as well as allegations of mismanagement of public funds 10 11 The movement expanded to encompass broader issues of governance transparency and political accountability 12 13 14 15 The protests escalated with police violence against children and hospitals 16 protests against public officials and vandalism of government and political buildings taking place throughout the country On 9 September 2025 Prime Minister K P Sharma Oli along with a few government ministers resigned On 12 September Sushi la Kar ki was appointed as interim prime minister of Nepal The protests had died down by 13 September 17 18 At least 76 people were killed of these one was a 12 year old child and at least 19 were young students At least 34 protesters died from gunshot wounds 16 On 4 September 2025 the Government of Nepal ordered the shutdown of 26 social media platforms including Facebook X YouTube Linked In Reddit Signal and Snap chat for failing to register under the Ministry of Communication and Information Technology's new rules 14 According to People's Dispatch the registration requirement had been motivated in part as a way to enable the enforcement of a new Digital Services Tax and stricter value added tax rules on foreign e service providers in an effort to boost revenue 19 better source needed However critics alleged the shutdown was prompted by a social media trend highlighting nepotism focusing on the undue privileges enjoyed by the children and relatives of influential political leaders 20 According to People's Dispatch the media platform ban had a significant impact on Nepalese political economy 33 of the Nepalese GDP comes from remittances with hundreds of thousands of exit permits being issued alongside 20 youth unemployment These remittances keep thousands of households afloat and pay import bills and also indicate a lack of structural transformation in the domestic economy toward an employment first model pushing the youth into work in online spaces 19 better source needed Banning social media thus threatened youth livelihood citation needed Prior to the protests the average Nepali citizen made US 1 400 per year 21 while families of the country's ruling elite displayed their wealth on social media This Ne po Kid trend prompted significant public anger particularly from Generation Z users 20 22 The median age of Nepal's population is 25 meaning that a large part of the population is in Gen Z the age group that uses social media the most This relatively young population combined with the country's largely rural rough terrain and substantial migration abroad leads Nepal to have some of the highest social media usage in South Asia 48 of Nepalese have a social media account while only 33 7 of Indians have a social media account 23 Youth participatory groups particularly Ham i Nepal 24 an on governmental organization used Discord online communities called servers in Discord b and Insta gram channels as central organising tools in the Gen Z protests 25 26 Anyone could join the Ham i Nepal Discord group making it vulnerable to trolls or people not living in Nepal 27 According to India Today messages in the Ham i Nepal discord advocated for violence against the Nepalese leadership 5 Tactical discussions on Discord included procurement and use of Molotov cocktails suggestions to seize ammunition from police stations and instructions on disabling aeroplane tyres using acetylene gas After police response led to 19 deaths organisers in some Discord servers asked members to stop attending classes They called for an indefinite closure of colleges and schools until the government accepted accountability for the fatalities 28 Protestors used VPN s and posted flyers with QR codes to evade the social media ban 29 After Oli's resignation the army's chiefs met with Ham i Nepal and asked them to suggest nominees for an interim leader who would oversee national elections On a Discord server with over 100 000 members 27 more than 10 000 users 26 met virtually in a Discord channel c to debate After discussions several polls and the use of sub channels for fact checking 26 the members settled on Sushi la Kar ki S has wot La mich han e who established the Discord server 27 and served as a channel moderator was a recent graduate with a background in science and technology 30 He played a pivotal role in the technical coordination that underpinned these exercises in digital democracy explaining that the discussions were meant to simulate a mini election 27 Supporters of the process were seen by Al Jazeera English as viewing the online process as a revolutionary counter to the traditional practice of politicians choosing leaders behind closed doors which had displayed little transparency 26 Sudan Gurung founder of the youth organization Ham i Nepal and widely regarded as one of the central figures of the 2025 Gen Z protests emerged as a leading voice advocating for transparency and digital democracy Gurung coordinated online discussions through Discord and served as a liaison between protest organizers and the Nepali Army during the transition period that followed Prime Minister K P Sharma Oli's resignation 31 32 33 Large gatherings took place in Kathmandu 9 particularly atM a it i ghar Mandala and around the federal parliament building New Banes h wor with tens of thousands of participants 34 35 The protests were originally organized as a peaceful rally by Ham i Nepal 5 an NGO 36 37 whose website highlights earthquake relief projects 38 An il Bani ya one of the protest organisers from Ham i Nepal said the government cracked down on the protesters after Meg raj Giri another protester threw a rock at a CCTV camera Bani ya stated that what began as a peaceful protest was hijacked by external forces and political party cadres but that regardless the government should not have responded to stones being thrown with live ammunition from the armed police 21 The Straw Hat Pirates ' Jolly Roger flag from the manga series One Piece was used by some protesters in similar fashion to the 2025 Indonesian protests 39 The original protest grew and evolved to a movement with no formal leadership individuals joined voluntarily in opposition to corruption and the social media ban The demonstrations escalated when protesters attempted to enter the Federal Parliament of Nepal leading security forces to respond with tear gas water cannons rubber bullets and live ammunition 40 Video Geo location published in the evening showed numerous victims killed in front of the parliament building Victims were seen lying inanimate on the ground many with serious or fatal wounds to the head and torso Videos showed victims with their faces blown off An expert identified bullets fired as coming from a lightweight 7 62 x 51 mm automatic rifle 41 The Kathmandu District Administration Office imposed a curfew in parts of the capital near government buildings However protests continued 21 The confrontations resulted in at least 19 people killed and more than 347 people injured 42 40 43 Seventeen of those protesters were killed in the capital 41 The National Human Rights Commission called on authorities not to use excessive force and to show restraint in handling the protests 44 In the evening the government lifted the ban on social media platforms 45 Home Minister Ramesh Lek hak resigned 46 A curfew was imposed in several major cities including Kathmandu Bir gun j B hair a haw a But wal Pokhara It a hari and Dama k 47 Following this protests for the complete dissolution of parliament began This was primarily caused by the initial government response to the original protests 21 Prime Minister K P Sharma Oli began the day with a call to all parties to cease violent action but he did not respond to the corruption allegations 1 Then he directed his Communist Party of Nepal Unified Marxist Leninist ministers not to resign their posts and resigned his own office 1 48 Afterwards Oli fled to an army barracks outside of Kathmandu Valley as per his interview in Kant i pur's fireside 49 There were conflicting reports on whether President Ram Chandra Po u del resigned as well as the Nepalese Army denied reports of Po u del's resignation 50 51 52 Despite this protests continued nationwide Protestors set fire to many government buildings part of Singh a Durbar the administrative headquarters of Nepal 53 the adjacent building of the Supreme Court of Nepal 54 the president's residence at S it al Ni was 55 56 57 the prime minister's residence at Bal uwa tar 58 and the headquarters of the Communist Party UML 59 Multiple reports allege that Nepali Army commander Ashok Raj Sig del advised Oli to resign in order for the Army to restore peace 60 Protest actions targeted several prominent locations in Kathmandu including the residences of the prime minister and the president as well as the homes of various government ministers and members of parliament which were set ablaze by protesters 61 The parliament building was set on fire 62 The headquarters of the UML and Nepali Congress was vandalized with party flags stripped and burned 63 Security forces including the Nepali Army facilitated the safe evacuation of politicians from affected areas and evacuated to Tri b hu van International Airport TIA while attempting to control the escalating incidents of arson and destruction 64 65 Minister of Agriculture Ram Nath Ad hikari and Health MinisterPr a dip Pau del along with 21 MPs from the Ras tri ya Sw a tantra Party resigned 66 along with all the MPs of the Ras tri ya P raja tantra Party 67 Several members left Oli's UML party 68 Protestors went to TIA to block the political leaders from fleeing The airport was closed and occupied by the Nepali Army 69 70 There was ensuing confusion as hundreds of travelers were left stranded in the TIA prompted airlines to order personnel to keep all individuals sheltered within the airport 71 72 Scheduled international flights were diverted to Pokhara or cancelled 73 Kant i pur media house was set on fire in the early evening 74 The online news portal was stopped due to damage in its server forcing it to post in Facebook as an alternative 75 Other buildings burned by protesters were the new Hilton Hotel in Kathmandu and the Ministry of Health building in Ram shah path 76 Several political leaders and their residences were attacked Former prime ministerS her Bahadur De ub a and his wife foreign minister Ar zu Rana De ub a were injured while their house was set on fire They were handed over to the police by protestors 77 Deputy prime minister Prakash Man Singh's house and vehicle were set on fire 78 followed by the house of former president Bid ya Devi Bh and a riat B hang al Kathmandu 79 Former prime minister Jhal a Nath Khan al's residence was also set on fire critically injuring his wife Ravi Laxmi Chitra kar 80 The residence of Ramesh Lek hak was also set on fire in Nai kap Kathmandu 81 In Rup and e hi district the houses of local politicians Bal Krishna Kh and Bh oj Prasad Sh rest ha and several mayors were burned 82 InCh it wan District the house of former prime ministerPr ach and a was set on fire 83 His daughter Ganga Dahal's house was also set on fire at Lalitpur A person was found dead the next day in the house 84 In He tau da several government offices were vandalized and set on fire 85 In Karn ali Province the parliament building and the residence of chief minister Yam Lal Kandel was set on fire 86 87 In Bir at nagar the capital of Koshi Province the district office and district court were set on fire followed by the residence of the chief minister and cabinet ministers 88 The prison in Kai la li district was attacked by the protestors All inmates fled 89 Rabi La mich ha new as set free from the Nak hu Jail in Kathmandu the prison was later set on fire all prisoners fled 90 91 Ka ski prison was also set on fire resulting in the escape of 773 inmates 92 In Bank e District five inmates were killed after security forces opened fire during a jailbreak at a juvenile correctional facility 93 The building of the Road Department was severely damaged after being set on fire by protestors 94 along with the office of Commission for the Investigation of Abuse of Authority 95 The lower station of the Chandra giri Cable Car was also set on fire along with the CG Electronics Digital Park Ba lamb u and Than kot Police Station 96 Several protesters were injured Thirty three were treated in the Teaching Hospital 97 Three policemen died in Kote sh wor 98 Curfew was imposed in several cities including Kathmandu Bir gun j B hair a haw a But wal Pokhara It a hari and Dama k 47 Additionally the police and armed forces began going house by house near the protests searching for protesters and raided the Civil Service Hospital where wounded and dying protesters were taken after being shot or otherwise beaten by government forces 21 Tear gas was shot into the hospital 16 A friendly football match between Nepal and Bangladesh that was scheduled for 9 September at the Dash a rath Stadium was cancelled because of the events in Nepal 99 Talks about restoring the monarchy re emerged with former king Gy an end ra emerging as a symbol of resistance for those disillusioned with the current political system particularly from the royalist opposition to the post Nepali civil war governments Earlier in the year monarchists protested calling for a restoration ending with a heavy crackdown that caused at least two deaths 100 However organizers urged not to resurface pro monarchy sentiment nor hold the Nepali flag as they believed it was a royal form of ultra nationalism Authors and scholars began to debate the actual intention of these comments and whether protesters really wanted a restoration of the monarchy 101 At around 22 00 NPT the Nepali Army stated that it would take charge of the country in the absence of the prime minister to ensure law and order is maintained 102 103 The press release called for cooperation as they deployed troops later that evening into the early hours of the following day 104 Later in the evening the Chief of Army Staff Ashok Raj Sig del appealed to the agitating groups for talks 105 In the early morning Nepali Army forces were seen patrolling neighborhoods in critical areas 106 General Sig del again encouraged protesters to remain peaceful as the government attempts to restore peace 71 107 Between approximately 10 00 NPT on 9 September and 22 00 NPT on 10 September the Army announced detention of 27 individuals on counts of looting arson and other destructive and anarchic activities and seizing weaponry 108 Later reports counted 31 firearms 93 In some places protestors continued raiding government buildings and politicians ' homes through the night with one video showing a group of protestors taking firearms from homes including what is believed to be a GSG 522 carbine and a bolt action rifle 93 109 The pace was slowed down by noon A group of protestors started cleaning the street near the parliament building that was set on fire the previous day 110 Many army weapons were captured by protesters One video included armor vests L 1 A 1 SLR rifles 37 mm Web ley Scott S cher mul y grenade launchers IN S AS 1 B 1 rifles Lee Enfield rifles and Isha pore 1 A 1 rifles 111 Protestors held online discussions on Discord to select an interim leader Around 10 00 pm NPT the group voted and selected Sushi la Kar ki 112 Bale n Shah mayor of Kathmandu and Kul Man G his ing were other candidates Bale n reportedly did not pick up the phone 113 Durga Pr asai separately met with the army chief but no concrete conclusion was met 114 Kar ki confirmed her willingness to accept the role in an interview with News 18 115 In Pokhara two dead bodies were found inside a burned house at Naya bazar and Lakeside 110 Police stated that as of 10 September more than 13 500 prisoners had escaped from prisons nationwide 116 Soldiers arrested 303 of those prisoners and handed them over to police Seventy three rifles were also returned 84 In D had ing District two inmates were shot dead and seven injured by soldiers when they tried to flee 117 while soldiers also thwarted an attempted jailbreak in Kathmandu's main prison 118 TIA's closure was extended late in the morning but eventually resumed operations 93 119 The New York Times reported that more than 100 000 citizens were using Discord an online communication software to select a nominee for interim leader The server described as the Parliament of Nepal had jumped to 145 000 members The server had reportedly settled on Sushi la Kar ki the country's former chief justice and proposed her name for meetings with the Army 27 In the morning a meeting was held that included President Ram Chandra Po u del Nepali Army Chief Ashok Raj Sig deland Gen Z representatives The meeting was held at Bhadrakali army headquarters as part of efforts to select an interim leader The Gen Z group advocated for Sushi la Kar ki to be interim prime minister Bale ndra Shah Kul Man G his ing and mayor of Dha ran Hark a Raj Rai were also considered 120 The Communist Party of Nepal Maoist Centre announced its support for the protests with party chairperson Push pa Kamal Dahal urging protestors to work within the democratic framework 121 Meanwhile the death toll increased to 34 while more than 1 300 people were injured according to Nepal's Ministry of Health and Population MoH P 122 According to police spokesperson Bin od G him ire the dead include 21 protesters nine prisoners three police officers and 18 others 123 124 G him ire confirmed that more than 12 500 fugitives remain at large after escaping from various prisons in Nepal Some tried to cross into India where they were apprehended by Indian border forces 125 126 Sushi la Kar ki a former Supreme Court chief justice was inaugurated as interim prime minister She is the first female prime minister in the history of Nepal 127 128 Shortly afterwards president Po u del dissolved parliament and set 5 March as the date for the next election 129 130 The curfew was lifted in the Kathmandu area 131 Prime Minister Kar ki began visiting injured protesters in hospitals 132 Deutsche Welle reported that calm appeared to have returned to the streets of the capital and that normal daily activities had resumed 133 At least 76 people were killed in the protests 6 of these one was a 12 year old child and at least 19 were young students At least 34 protesters died from gunshot wounds to the head chest abdomen and neck confirmed by autopsy 16 At least 2 113 were injured 134 Search teams were dispatched to recover bodies from all structures set on fire according to the MoH P 135 A day of national mourning for the victims was held on 17 September 2025 136 Protests destroyed numerous public offices destroying equipment of essential services Spared offices continued to operate normally while burned offices pitched tents and scraped together materials to resume services 137 According to officials from Sushi la Kar ki's interim government any family who lost a member in the protests would receive monetary compensation of 1 million Nepalese rupees maximum amount allowed by the law equivalent to aboutUS 7 000 as of September 2025 138 139 Those who were injured during the protests would also be compensated At the same meeting she called out for unity in order to rebuild the country 128 The day Kar ki took office on 14 September she urged calm and cooperation to rebuild following the protests 140 She also condemned the destruction caused by protests and claimed that some of the arson was premeditated She also criticised those who caused damage and pledged to investigate conspiracies behind the violence intending to spare nobody 141 Kar ki said that she would remain in power for no more than six months 140 After the parliament were dissolved and elections were announced for 5 March 2026 mainstream political forces faced debate for change in leadership In the meantime new parties were registered by popular personalities to take part in the election announced Nepali Congress Party youth leaders including Gag an Th apa B is hwa Prakash Sharma and Pra dip Pau del led a debate within party and proposed party convention to be conducted before election to bring reform in the party 142 Amidst such discussions S her Bahadur De ub a became first politician of any mainstream major party to hand over leadership assigning party vice president P urna Bahadur K had kaas acting president 143 CP N UML Debate for call for restructuring of leadership raised by leaders Ishwar Pok h rel Yog es h Bhatt arai and others Oli did not step down as party chair Despite widely criticized for up rise and destruction Oli called party convention in Kathmandu pleading for HoR reinstatement as he was bared from going outside valley 144 Publicly Mahesh Bas net was widely criticized for providing protection and royal treatment to him 145 CP N Maoist Centre While party chair Dahal resigned as party chair he declared himself as party coordinator till party convention would be conducted 146 The party then merged with eight different parties including M adha v Kumar Nepal led CP N Unified Socialist to form Nepali Communist Party 147 In the eve of unification a group led by former ministers and party portfolios Jan ard an Sharma Ram Kar ki and Sudan Kira ti declared Progressive Campaign Nepal 148 Ras tri ya Sw a tantra Party Party faced criticism for leader worship when Sum an a Sh rest ha left party while leaders including Ganesh Kar ki and Toshima Kar ki faced setback within party for criticizing leadership 149 Later chief whip Santosh Par i yar left the party and joined hands with Babur am Bhatt arai and Jan ard an Sharma to form Progressive Citizens ' Party 150 151 Regional party Jana mat faced a split when chief minister Satish Kumar Singh sided split under Jana swaraj Party and senior leader along with spokesperson left party asking for end to leader worship 152 153 Parties were registered under the leadership of Hark a Sampan g Bir end ra Bahadur Bas net while a party named Uj ya alo Nepal Party was formed by Kul Man G his in gas an alternative force 154 155 Former Minister of Justice Gobind a Bandi said the social media ban goes against the constitution and basic freedoms including rights protected by Nepal's constitution and the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights I CCPR 156 The Ras tri ya P raja tantra Party R PP part of the opposition condemned the social media ban and the police response to the protests and called for the immediate dissolution of the current government 157 In a Facebook post Kathmandu's mayor Bale ndra Shah said he could not attend the protests because of the age limit set by the organizers However he believed it was important to listen to their voices 158 President Ram Chandra P oude land the Nepalese army appealed for calm and political dialogue 159 Gy an end ra the former King of Nepal issued a statement condemning the violent crackdown on the protests and calling on the government to listen to the demands of the protesters He further urged the protest movement to remain peaceful and avoid being hijacked by criminal elements 160 Various hotels in Pokhara's lakeside area were set on fire during the protests The Hotel Association Pokhara Nepal called for an investigation on the vandalism and for government compensation as Pokhara's tourism industry was heavily hit 161 162 In October Nepalese physicians pleaded to the UN Human Rights Council to investigate the human rights violations against children and health care personnel They have asked the UN International Children's Emergency Fund and the WHO to help the victims 16 The unrest in Nepal impacted activities along the India Nepal border Local sources noted that markets had fallen silent causing larger economic stagnation across neighbouring regions Shortly after the worries the Maharashtra State Emergency Operations Centre SEO C issued a travel advisory on 9 September requesting Indian citizens not to travel until further notice It made emergency help lines available and encouraged both Indian and Nepali citizens in Nepal to also remain in place 71 163 Early in the morning of 10 September Air India IndiGo Spice Jet and several other Indian airlines officially cancelled all flights in and out of Tri b hu van International Airport commonly known as TIA 71 After TIA was reopened later that day IndiGo resumed flights 164 However sources from inside TIA reported that the airport was still at a standstill with little communication of updates from authorities 165 India's Ministry of External Affairs said it was closely monitoring the protests expressing grief over the casualties and extending condolences to the victims ' families It also wished a speedy recovery for the injured and advised Indian citizens in Nepal to follow curfew orders and safety guidelines 166 167 168 The Bangladeshi Ministry of Foreign Affairs stated that it was closely monitoring the situation in Nepal while expressing condolences to the families of the deceased and wishing recovery to the injured It also stated that it hoped a peaceful and constructive dialogue among all relevant parties in the country to resolve any kind of differences 169 The military leader of Myanmar Min Aung H laing stated during a meeting with the State Security and Peace Commission that lessons should be learned from the outside interference in Nepal 170 171 United Nations Secretary General Ant nio Gu terre s's spokesman St phane Du jar ric said the secretary general was deeply saddened by the loss of life and called on the authorities to comply with international human rights law and for the protestors to respect life and property 172 Volker T rk the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights said he was appalled by the escalating violence and called on the security forces to exercise the utmost restraint 173 He also called for an investigation into conduct of the security forces particularly the deaths of protestors and reports of disproportionate use of force 174 Amnesty International condemned the crackdown and called for independent investigation and accountability on 8 September It called for a de escalation while urging authorities to exercise maximum restraint in its use of force It supported the protesters rights to protest peacefully and demanded the government heed the legitimate demands of the youth to end corruption to reestablish civil liberties 175 Human Rights Watch did not immediately make a statement on the protests but suggested certain actions in a news report on 9 September Its statements were supported by findings that the Nepali government has a record of silencing online speech which fueled growing discontent in younger population Citing the ban's lifting and rampant militaristic police violence it suggested that Nepali authorities should promptly and impartially investigate the police use of force and appropriately discipline or prosecute all those responsible for abuses regardless of rank Its Asia director Meenakshi Gang u ly underscored that the police shootings shows the administration's appalling disregard for the lives of its own citizens and desperate need to suppress criticism It further cited the UN Basic Principles on the Use of Force and Firearms and tracking of the UN Human Rights Committee to argue that the government's use of live ammunition was extra judicial 176 The International Federation for Human Rights and World Organisation Against Torture released a joint statement condemning the crackdown on peaceful protests on 9 September It called for the government to immediately halt all forms of violation and brutality by authorities against protesters ensure that the ban rollback was permanent through legal means and to uphold its state party status to the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights OH CHR and the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights I CCPR by maintaining respect for the fundamental rights of its people both online and offline 177
